I.  THE ENSUING PROGRAM 
 
1.  Gross domestic product in Georgia grew at an average annual rate of 5.3% during 
2004–2017, supported by reforms to liberalize the economy, mitigate bureaucratic barriers, and 
combat corruption. Domestic product growth accelerated from 2.8% in 2016 to 4.8% in 2017, 
remained the same in 2018, and is projected to increase to 5.0% in 2019. Georgia ranked sixth 
out of 190 economies in the World Bank’s  Doing Business index in 2018.1 The improved 
business environment is central to the country’s private sector-led development model and has 
involved  major  economic  management  and  governance  reforms.  While  the  business 
environment  has  improved,  barriers  to  private  sector  competitiveness  remain,  including 
unemployment and a skills mismatch. In 2018, the overall unemployment rate was 14.1%, but 
the unemployment rate stood at 30.8% for those aged 20–24 and 26.6% for those aged 15–19.2 
More than 40% of employment is in agriculture, fishing, and forestry; the wholesale and retail 
trade, repair of motor vehicles and motorcycles, education, and industry are also important. 
 
2.  Vocational education and training (VET) programs are offered primarily in vocational 
colleges  and  community  colleges,  as  well  as  in  a  few  higher  education  institutions  and 
secondary schools. In 2018, 118 providers offered VET programs: 34 vocational colleges, 51 
community colleges, 23 higher education institutions, and 10 secondary schools (footnote 2). 
Vocational colleges offer the first three levels of VET programs, while community colleges offer 
preparatory  general  education,  liberal  arts,  and  VET  programs.  VET  enrollments  fell  from 
21,000 in 2013 to 11,800 in 2018, partly because of recent changes to VET program structure 
and length. VET enrollments represented only 1.6% of 15–24-year-olds. By comparison, 30.7% 
of 15−24-year-olds were enrolled in higher education. The Government of Georgia’s ambitious 
goal is to increase VET enrollments to 11.0% of those aged 15−24 by 2021. Private VET is 
significant – representing two-thirds of providers and one-third of enrollments in 2018. 
 
3.  Cultural norms limit female participation in VET and in the labor market, and result in 
significant occupational segregation. Fewer young women are in employment (30%) than young 
men (50%). The labor force participation and employment rates for males are higher than for 
females because most young men transition directly from school to work, while most young 
women remain inactive for a time.3 The unemployment rate for men is higher than that for 
women.  Average  monthly  earnings  of  men  are  higher  than  those  of  women.  There  is 
considerable occupational segregation in the labor market, with women making up about 75% of 
employees in the health care and social sectors and 60% of those in the hospitality sector. 
Women  account  for  fewer  than  10%  of  construction  workers  and  23%  of  transport  and 
communications workers (footnote 2). 
 
4.  Since 2013, the government has focused on improving the performance of the VET 
subsector, including through the adoption of the VET Strategy, 2013−2020 and the Unified 
Strategy for Education and Science, 2017–20214 and the passage of the Law of Georgia on 
Vocational Education, 2018. The government’s reform program has been accompanied by 
increased spending on VET and has introduced comprehensive reforms to the VET system. A 
focus of these reforms and development partners’ efforts has been to better align the VET

subsector with labor market needs and facilitate private sector participation in VET. Despite 
these efforts, the VET subsector faces the twin challenges of increasing the supply of skills 
while ensuring that training is relevant to the needs of the labor market and supports the 
transition to a higher valued-added economy. 
 
5.  Skills mismatch. The mismatch between the skills produced by the VET system and 
those required in the labor market manifests itself in various ways, including scarcity of skilled 
workers,  over-qualification  among  the  employed,  and  a  lack  of  generic  cognitive  and 
socioeconomic skills. A 2015 labor market survey identified lack of skills as a key reason for 
firms’ inability to fill vacancies.5 While employers mainly demand workers with technical skills, 
most job seekers are university graduates (footnote 5). However, a 2014 tracer study of VET 
graduates  found  that  only  42%  of  graduates  were  in  employment.6 A  survey  of  business 
demand for skills showed that 92% of firms found it difficult to fill vacancies, and that this was 
worse for technical (blue collar) positions than for professional (white collar) positions.7 The 
main reason cited was that candidates lacked the required qualifications.  
 
6.  A 2018 study found evidence of a significant skills mismatch in the Georgian labor 
market.8 While students can access higher education, many find it difficult to get a job after they 
graduate. More than 50% of the unemployed had a secondary school diploma and 40% had a 
higher education qualification. Graduates lack the technical skills required in the labor market, 
as  well  as  soft  skills  such  as  creative  and  critical  thinking,  problem  solving,  teamwork, 
leadership, and decision-making. Skills gaps in Georgia may worsen given that new economy 
skills  are  in  particularly  short  supply,  and  the  more  dynamic  and  innovative  firms  may 
experience more significant skills gaps. Skills gaps negatively affect workers and firms by 
reducing earnings potential, job creation, and productivity; and hindering investment (footnote 5). 
 
7.  Poor quality and relevance. A key factor driving the weak performance of the VET 
subsector is the poor quality and relevance of the VET imparted to trainees. Although Georgia 
ranked 45th out of 140 countries on the skills pillar of the Global Competitiveness Index, 2018–
2019, it ranked poorly on key components such as the extent of staff training (112th), quality of 
vocational training (131st), skillset of graduates (123rd), and ease of finding skilled employees 
(111th). Several factors contribute to the poor performance of the VET sector in Georgia, as 
discussed below.  
 
8.  Lack of private sector and stakeholder participation. The limited engagement of 
employers and stakeholders has hindered improvements in the quality and relevance of VET 
programs. In 2009, the government created the National VET Council, a tripartite advisory and 
consultative body to support VET development and coordinate among government agencies, 
employers,  trade  unions,  the  nongovernment  sector,  and  VET  institutes.  In  2010,  the 
government created 14 sector committees under the National Center for Educational Quality 
Enhancement,  tasked with  developing  occupational  standards.  These  no  longer  exist.  The 
passage of the Law of Georgia on Public–Private Partnerships, 2018 and amendments to the

Law of Georgia on Vocational Education, 2018 established a framework to institutionalize VET 
institute−industry partnerships, although their use is limited.9 
 
9.  Poor quality teaching workforce. Attracting, training, and retraining VET teachers are 
major challenges for the VET system in Georgia. There is little evidence on the quality of the 
teaching workforce, although stakeholders have expressed concern that most VET teachers 
have little practical knowledge. There is no pre- or in-service training for VET teachers, although 
the  Ministry  of  Education,  Science,  Culture  and  Sport  (MOESCS)  is  developing  one. 
Professional development for VET teachers focuses on pedagogical issues. Low pay for VET 
teachers and a centrally driven pay system make it difficult to attract and retain good teachers, 
which exacerbates the situation. The MOESCS is developing a salary scheme that will link VET 
teacher pay to qualifications and industry experience. 
 
10.  Uneven access. Georgia has made significant progress in increasing the geographical 
coverage of VET provision throughout the country. There is public sector VET provision in all 
regions of the country and private sector provision in all but one region. However, a nationwide 
flexible network of public and private VET providers accessible to all regardless of social status, 
geographical location, gender, and ability remains a challenge, especially for women, ethnic 
minorities, persons with disabilities, and those in rural areas. The urban–rural divide is growing. 
The proportion of youth who were not in employment, education, or training in 2013 stood at 
31% for those aged 15–24 and 35% for those aged 15–29. 
 
11.  Poor image and reputation. As in many other countries, another factor hindering the 
development of the VET subsector is that it is not seen as an attractive educational pathway for 
skills acquisition. Students and parents see limited value in VET and prefer higher education as 
a route to increased lifetime earnings and improved career opportunities. The perception in 
Georgia is that only students with low grades pursue VET. This is made worse by perceptions of 
the low quality and relevance of VET and the fact that, until recently, VET studies represented a 
dead end given the lack of links between VET and other levels of education. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
12.  The transaction technical assistance (TA) will help prepare the program. The TA is 
justified given the scope of the policy matrix and program activities and the specialized nature of 
skills required in areas such as centers of excellence (COEs) and public–private partnerships.10 
The TA will provide technical inputs and assessments. It is also aligned with the proposed 
direction of the country partnership strategy for Georgia, 2019–2023 of the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB), which is expected to be approved in late 2019. The program is in ADB’s country 
operations business plan for Georgia, 2019–2021 as a firm 2020 program; the TA is in ADB’s 
country operations business plan for Georgia, 2019–2021 as a 2019 nonlending project. 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
13.  Output 1: Detailed policy matrix and program design developed. This output will (i) 
develop the policy matrix; (ii) design the program, including COEs, public–private partnership 
programs,  career  guidance,  secondary  school  VET,  and  competency-based  training  and

assessment; (iii) prepare detailed program costings, including civil works, consultancy, capacity 
building,  and  program  implementation;  (iv)  prepare  the  design  and  monitoring  framework, 
including  specification  of  performance  indicators  and  program  activities;  (v)  identify  sector 
capacity-building  requirements,  program  VET  institutes,  and  priority  economic  sectors;  (vi) 
prepare initial architectural designs for program general secondary schools and VET institutes; 
(vii) develop the program procurement plan and program implementation plan. 
 
14.   Output 2: Program due diligence undertaken. This output will support program due 
diligence, including the (i) VET sector assessment; (ii) environmental assessment; (iii) economic 
and financial analysis; (iv) gender, poverty, and social analyses; (v) financial management 
assessment  of  the  program’s  executing  agencies;  (vi)  procurement  capacity  and  financial 
management assessments of the executing agencies; (vii) procurement risk assessment and 
procurement classification; (viii) social safeguards assessments; and (ix) risk assessment and 
management plan. 
 
15.  Output 3: Program processing and implementation start-up facilitated. This output 
will include assisting in the preparation of all documents required for program processing, 
including the (i) report and recommendation of the President and all linked documents; (ii) policy 
matrix; (iii) project administration manual; and (iv) project start-up and implementation support, 
including assisting the executing agency in recruiting project implementation unit staff. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $0.83 million, of which $0.70 million will be financed on a 
grant  basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-other  sources).  The  key 
expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1. The government will provide counterpart support in 
the form of exemptions on taxes and duties, counterpart staff, office accommodation, and other 
in-kind contributions. The government was informed that approval of the TA does not commit 
ADB to finance any ensuing program. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  ADB will administer the TA. The MOESCS will be the executing agency. The Social 
Sector Division of the Central and West Asia Department will coordinate program preparation 
and implementation with the MOESCS. The TA will be implemented from September 2019 to 
August  2021  to  ensure  effective  program  preparation  and  start-up.  The  implementation 
arrangements are summarized in Table 1.
